title: Japan’s ispace warns of delays in new lunar lander engine
summary:
Japanese lunar company ispace said work on a new engine for its lunar landers is facing delays and that it is keeping open the option of switching engines.
The post Japan’s ispace warns of delays in new lunar lander engine appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: SSC Space Opens Orbital Launch Control Center at Esrange
summary:
SSC Space has officially opened the Esrange Space Center’s new Orbital Launch Control Center, which will be used to manage future rocket launches from the facility. The Esrange Space Center in northern Sweden has hosted suborbital rocket launches since the 1960s. In October 2020, the Swedish government and the Swedish Space Corporation (SSC), now known […]
The post SSC Space Opens Orbital Launch Control Center at Esrange appeared first on European Spaceflight.

title: Northern Glow Spans Iceland and Canada
summary: A vivid display of the aurora lit up skies over the Denmark Strait and eastern Canada during a minor geomagnetic storm in February 2026.

title: Pentagon seeks commercially built GEO spy satellites
summary:
The Defense Innovation Unit plans to select companies to field and operate spacecraft before transferring them to government control within three years
The post Pentagon seeks commercially built GEO spy satellites  appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: Digital Surface and Terrain Models from Vantor’s Precision3D Product Line Added to Satellite Data Explorer
summary: The CSDA Program added three digital elevation and digital terrain products from Vantor’s Precision3D Product Line to the Satellite Data Explorer.

title: Vantor Archive Imagery Added to Satellite Data Explorer
summary: NASA’s Commercial Satellite Data Acquisition (CSDA) Program announces the addition of imagery from Vantor to its Satellite Data Explorer (SDX) data access and discovery tool.

title: CSDA Releases New Data Acquisition Request System
summary: The CSDA Program’s Data Acquisition Request System lets authorized users submit proposals for yet-to-be-collected data from CSDA’s commercial partners.

title: CSDA Program Announces Eight New Data Agreements
summary: NASA’s Commercial Satellite Data Acquisition (CSDA) Program announced eight new agreements with seven of its commercial partners to give users more access to near‑global multispectral and synthetic aperture radar data.

title: Notes from the Field
summary: Looking at Chlorophyll from Space By Compton “Jim” Tucker NASA scientists are able to study plants from space, but this wasn’t always the case. “I love using satellite data to study the Earth,” says Dr. Compton “Jim” Tucker. When Tucker was a graduate student, he and some friends discovered a new way to study photosynthesis. […]

title: 42 Years of Measuring the Sun, the Earth and the Energy in Between
summary: By Denise Lineberry On Jan. 31, 1958, Explorer 1 became the first satellite launched by the United States. Its primary science instrument, a cosmic ray detector, was designed to measure the radiation environment in Earth orbit. Though its final transmission was in May 1958, it continued to revolve around Earth more than 58,000 times. As […]
